    Small Molecule Approaches for Targeting the Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2) in Cancer

    • M. Cynthia Martin
      M. Cynthia Martin

    Abstract

    The polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2) is composed of three core subunits, enhancer of zeste 2 (EZH2), embryonic ectoderm development (EED), and suppressor of zeste 12 (SUZ12), along with a number of accessory proteins. It is the key enzymatic protein complex that catalyzes histone H3 lysine 27 (H3K27) methylation to mediate epigenetic silencing of target genes. PRC2 thus plays essential roles in maintaining embryonic stem cell identity and in controlling cellular differentiation. Studies in the past decade have reported frequent overexpression or mutation of PRC2 in various cancers including prostate cancer and lymphoma. Aberrant PRC2 function has been extensively studied and proven to contribute to a large number of abnormal cellular processes, including those that lead to uncontrolled proliferation and tumorigenesis. Significant efforts have recently been made to develop small molecules targeting PRC2 function for potential use as anticancer therapeutics. In this review, we describe recent approaches to identify and develop small molecules that target PRC2. These various strategies include the inhibition of the function of individual PRC2 core proteins, the disruption of PRC2 complex formation, and the degradation of its subunits.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2), well-known for its catalytic function specific on H3 lysine 27 (mono-, di-, or tri-) methylation and epigenetic silencing of target genes, is composed of three essential core subunits, enhancer of zeste 2 (EZH2), embryonic ectoderm development (EED), and suppressor of zeste 12 (SUZ12), and is essential for the maintenance of embryonic stem cell identify during development.(1â4) These core subunit proteins are required for the maintenance of repression of homeotic genes during development. EZH2, the main enzymatic subunit of PRC2, has a SET domain that contains the active site for the catalysis of histone H3 lysine 27 methylation.(5,6) EED is required to boost the catalytic activity of EZH2; it binds to H3K27me3 to stimulate the histone methyltransferase (HMTase) activity of the complex.(7â11) The interaction between EZH2 and EED is essential for PRC2 enzymatic activity.(12â15) SUZ12 stabilizes EZH2 and is necessary for HMTase activity and the silencing function of the EED-EZH2 complex.(16) Loss of SUZ12 leads to the global loss of H3K27me3 and the destabilization of EZH2.(17â20) Further, both EED and SUZ12 proteins are required for the stability of EZH2 on the chromatin and the subsequent H3K27 methylation.(21)
    PRC2 is the only known methyltransferase that specifically methylates H3K27 at different levels (mono-, di-, or tri-) through its HMTase activity, creating a binding site for the chromodomain-containing protein polycomb (Pc).(22â24) All three H3K27 methylation states have been correlated with transcriptional repression and heterochromatin formation,(25â29) while only H3K27me3 is tightly linked to gene silencing at specific loci through chromatin compaction.(30â35) In addition, H3K27me3 is linked to the repair of DNA damage, particularly the repair of double-strand breaks by homologous recombination repair.(36)
    PRC2 components have been reported to be overexpressed and highly disregulated in multiple types of cancers, including prostate, breast, lung, gastric bladder, pancreatic, and others, which have been thoroughly reviewed.(37â40) Overexpression of EZH2 and gain-of-function somatic mutation of EZH2 (such as Y641) have been causatively associated with the development and progression of solid tumors and hematopoietic cancers, respectively, through mediating epigenetic silencing of target genes.(41â45) Recently, more attention has been given to the noncanonical roles of PRC2 in various cancers. In addition to its methylation activity on H3K27, EZH2 and PRC2 have been reported to methylate a number of non-histone substrates to regulate their transcriptional activities or downstream signaling pathways.(14,46â50) Furthermore, recent studies have reported methylation-independent functions of EZH2 in collaborating with non-PRC2 transcription factors to activate target genes or signaling pathways.(20,51â54)
    Due to the critical roles PRC2 plays in multiple types of cancer, there has been intense interest in the development of new small molecule drugs for its therapeutic targeting. These strategies, with an emphasis on new therapeutic modalities such as EED-targeting and protein degradation, will be reviewed here (Figure 1). The first drug directly targeting PRC2, tazemetostat (EPZ-6438), trade name Tazverik, was approved in January, 2020, and is indicated for treating epithelioid sarcoma and follicular lymphoma. Epizyme is also developing tazemetostat in multiple clinical trials against other lymphomas and solid tumors. Besides tazemetostat, there are currently at least five additional distinct small molecule EZH2 inhibitors in clinical trials against various forms of cancer (Table 1). Constellation Pharmaceuticals is also testing multiple EZH2 inhibitors in clinical trials; CPI-1205 is their most advanced EZH2 inhibitor and is currently in phase 2 testing for metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC). Besides investigating CPI-1205 in other tumor types as well, the Constellation groupâs second-generation EZH2 inhibitor (CPI-0209) has also begun phase 1 testing for patients with solid tumors. The GlaxoSmithKline EZH2 inhibitor GSK2816126 was tested for pharmacokinetics (PK) in a phase 1 study (NCT02082977); however, further development was halted after PK data indicated that this compound was unlikely to provide any benefit. Besides EZH2 inhibitors, Novartis is currently studying the first EED inhibitor (MAK683, U.S. Patent 9,580,437) in a phase 1 trial (NCT02900651).
    Table 1. Clinical Development Status of Small Molecule Drugs Targeting PRC2 Complex Proteins
    drugasponsorphaseindicationsNCT IDcomments

    PF06821497Pfizer1SCLC, CRPC, lymphomaNCT03460977Recruiting

    a

    All compounds are EZH2 inhibitors unless otherwise noted.

    b

    Compound is an EED inhibitor. See the Abbreviations Used section at the end for the definitions of these abbreviations.

    2. Small Molecules That Inhibit PRC2

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Small molecules targeting PRC2 can be broadly classified by the specific PRC2 core subunit they target. On the basis of this system, PRC2-targeting small molecules have been divided into three main categories for further discussion in this review. The largest class covers the small molecules that inhibit the enzymatic activity of EZH2. The second category reports compounds that bind to EED and inhibit its interaction with H3K27. The remaining group of PRC2-directed agents bind either to EZH2 or EED and induce the degradation of the target protein, by the use of hydrophobic tags or ligands that recruit an E3 ligase to induce proteasomal degradation.

    2.1. EZH2 Catalytic Inhibitors

    Given the essential function EZH2 plays in H3K27 trimethylation and the role this histone mark has in cellular differentiation, proliferation, and tumorigenesis, a large number of enzymatic EZH2 inhibitors have been developed. Each of these molecules acts by inhibiting the enzymatic activity of the methyltransferase function of EZH2. Here we describe the most well-characterized and significant inhibitors reported to date. As they typically work by a similar mechanism of action, they have been differentiated here based on their structural features so that additional insights into structureâactivity relationships (SAR) can be drawn.
    When considering the structures of the most significant EZH2 catalytic inhibitors (Figure 2), it is noteworthy that they all contain the pyridone motif. The crystal structure of a representative inhibitor bound to EZH2 (PDB code 5LS6) shows a clear hydrogen bond framework between the pyridone NâH and CâO groups to the backbone amide of EZH2 W624. This interaction appears to provide sufficient affinity to anchor the inhibitor in the active site. The crystal structure of the S-adenosyl methionine (SAM) methyltransferase product S-adenosyl homocysteine (SAH, Figure 2) bound to EZH2 (PDB code 5HYN) shows that this same EZH2 W624 provides a critical hydrogen bond to the SAH terminal amino acid moiety. The competitive nature of pyridone-based inhibitors is evident by observing that the pyridone group occupies the same position as the SAH amino acid motif, thereby preventing simultaneous SAH/SAM binding. While it is understandable that inhibitors containing a pyridone group are able to bind to EZH2 through interaction with W624, it is nonetheless curious that there have been surprisingly few reports of EZH2 inhibitors that do not contain this group. It is possible that compound libraries enriched in pyridone-containing ligands have been used independently by different groups to identify hit starting points, although details of successes/failures in identifying non-pyridone-based inhibitors have not yet been reported.

    2.1.1. Pyridone Indole

    In an effort to develop EZH2 catalytic-site inhibitors, a group at Constellation Pharmaceuticals carried out a high throughput screening campaign to identify initial starting points.(55) Among the hits was CPI-905 (15), a pyridone-based inhibitor with weak activity (IC50 = 39.6 Î¼M) against EZH2 enzymatic activity. During medicinal chemistry optimization, this molecule was modified to generate a lead compound in which the original benzodiaxolane was replaced by an indole ring which had significantly improved properties (16, CPI-360, Figure 3). Further characterization of this compound showed it possessed excellent inhibitory potency (IC50 = 0.5 nM) of WT EZH2, was S-adenosyl-l-methionine (SAM)-competitive, and showed attractive selectivity for EZH2 across a large panel of histone lysine and arginine and DNA methyltransferases.
    On the basis of the potent characteristics of 16, scientists at Constellation Pharmaceuticals combined structural features of 15 with the SAM-competitive PRC2 inhibitor compound 17 (Figure 4).(56) The commonality of the benzoylamide motif between 17 and 15 led them to test the interchangeability of the tetramethylpiperidine with the dimethylpyridone as in compound 18. While significant potency was lost relative to 17, hybrid compound 18 showed improved potency relative to 15. In addition, they found that removal of the chloro, cyano, and pyridazine substituents and replacement with a phenoxyphenyl group (19) provided better potency in the dimethylpyridone series.
    Initial SAR based on compound 19 revealed that a methylene linker instead of the ether linker between the two phenyl rings led to a 3-fold improvement in potency (20, Figure 5). In an attempt to lower the logÂ P, polarity was introduced onto the central ring by introducing a 3-indolyl group (compound 21) which showed an 11-fold improvement in potency with sub-100 nM activity against both WT and mutant EZH2. Further modifications to the indole side chain showed preference for the R-enantiomer, providing submicromolar cell potency at inhibiting H3K27me3 in HeLa cells, leading to the new analog (22) with IC50 = 1 nM against EZH2. Finally, replacement of one of the methyl groups on the pyridone ring of 22 with a methoxy group provided a significant improvement in microsomal stability with similar biochemical and cellular potency, resulting in 23 (CPI-169, Figure 5), which was tested in a lymphoma xenograft model.
    The in vivo studies on 23 demonstrated good activity in a Karpas422 pharmacodynamic (PD) mouse model, with an approximately 84% reduction in tumor H3K27me3 after dosing at 200 mg/kg twice daily for 17 days. Compound 23 also produced strong antitumor efficacy (54%, 77%, and >100% tumor growth inhibition (TGI) at 50, 100, and 200 mg/kg, respectively) and little systemic toxicity (less than 10% body-weight loss). However, 23 had poor oral bioavailability in rats and dogs (0.09% F and 0.12% F, respectively), making its further development difficult. Therefore, additional medicinal chemistry optimization was carried out, focusing on different N-substituents on the piperidine ring.(57) The primary focus was on decreasing the piperidineâs basicity since perturbation of the piperidine pKa had been shown to affect cellular potency, selectivity, toxicity, bioavailability, and other pharmacokinetic (PK) properties.(58) A series of fluorinated analogs was synthesized, and it was found that the trifluoroethyl group on the piperidine ring showed comparable potency to 23 and good oral bioavailability. This led to a potent and selective inhibitor of EZH2 (4, CPI-1205, Figure 6) which is currently under evaluation in clinical trials for the treatment of B-cell lymphomas. At a single PO dose of 100 mg/kg, mouse pharmacokinetics studies showed compound 4 achieved an unbound Cmax of 1.41 Î¼M and an unbound exposure (area under the curve, AUC) of 1.87 Î¼MÂ·h while maintaining oral bioavailability of 100%.
    In the Karpas422 mouse B-cell lymphoma xenograft model, 4 significantly reduced tumor growth (TGI) by 97% after 25 daysâ treatment with twice-daily PO administration of 160 mg/kg. This also led to a substantial reduction of H3K27me3 (47%) without producing significant body weight loss. In addition, pharmacokinetic data showed that 4 possessed relatively high clearance and good oral bioavailability in both rats and dogs (44.6% and 46.2% F, respectively).(57)
    During studies on the development of 4, a cocrystal structure of a similar pyridone-containing inhibitor (13, Figure 6) bound to human PRC2 was obtained.(57) Electron density corresponding to compound 13 was identified in a pocket at the interface of the EZH2 SET domain, the SAL region of the EZH2 N-terminus, and EED. In addition, a partial overlap between the 2,2-difluoropropylpiperidine 13 and the SAH carboxylic acid was consistent with a SAM competitive mechanism of inhibition. Overall, the ligand adopted an interesting twisted conformation, likely due to a conformational preorganization induced by the chiral methyl group and the indoyl amide substituents that fit in the enzymeâs pocket. Additionally, the two potential hydrogen bond interactions between the pyridone motif and protein backbone Trp624 (Figure 6) help explain its high affinity binding and the pyridoneâs prevalence in a large number of EZH2 inhibitors.
    Even though 4 (CPI-1205) was found to be well-tolerated during phase 1 clinical trials,(59) it required high doses of the drug (800 mg, three times per day). At the same time, extended dosing of some EZH2 inhibitors has resulted in decreased drug exposure due to induction of CYP3A4 leading to increased metabolism of the drug.(60,61) This effect suggests the potential for drugâdrug interactions when using such high doses of EZH2 inhibitors as part of combination therapies. To further improve the extent of EZH2 enzyme inhibition and consequently the in vivo properties of their EZH2 inhibitor series, further lead optimization of 4 was undertaken. Scientists at Constellation Pharmaceuticals investigated the electronic characteristics of the pyridone ring, which led to 4-thiomethylpyridone(62) as a key modification (24, Figure 7), achieving a significant increase in potency (EZH2 IC50 = 0.2 nM) and prolonged residence time (10-fold improvement over 4). However, compound 24 showed a nearly 25-fold increase in CYP3A4 upregulation. Additional modifications around the piperidine side-chain and indole core were investigated, resulting in aza-indole 12 with improved potency (EZH2 IC50 = 0.057 nM), negligible CYP3A4 upregulation, longer residence time (57 h), and modest (15% F) oral bioavailability. On the basis of these properties, compound 12 was tested in a mouse xenograft model.
    Treatment of a Karpas422 lymphoma xenograft mouse model with aza-indole 12 displayed tumor regression at day 14 using a 25 mg/kg BID-PO dose. The study also showed a TGI of 75% at day 21, with no impact on mouse body weight. In addition, H3K27me3 was significantly decreased at day 14.(62) PK/PD studies showed that the unbound plasma concentration of 12 was maintained above the EC50 necessary to reduce H3K27me3 for 4 h.
    Scientists at Novartis carried out a high-throughput screen for new EZH2 inhibitors.(63) The resulting hit compound scaffold was used as a template for the design of compound 7 (El1, Figure 8). Since mutations in the SET domain of EZH2 would contribute to maintaining high levels of H3K27me3 which promotes cell proliferation, the authors examined the ability of 7 to inhibit proliferation in cell lines carrying wild-type and Y641F mutant EZH2. Compound 7 showed potent inhibition of WT EZH2 (IC50 = 15 nM) and Y641F mutant EZH2 (IC50 = 13 nM). They also found that 7 produced genome-wide loss of H3K27 methylation and activation of PRC2 target genes. They showed that treatment of diffused large B-cell lymphoma cell lines with inhibitor 7 was able to potently block tumor proliferation in cells carrying both wild-type and Y641 mutant EZH2.
    Scientists at Integral Biosciences have developed a series of potent EZH2 inhibitors that contained an increased fraction of sp3 carbons to increase the solubility of their inhibitors.(64,65) While keeping the 4,6-dimethylpyridone methyl amide constant, they incorporated a bicyclic nonplanar indoline core in place of the indole and evaluated the effect of substitution at R1 and R2 (Table 2). The isopropyl substituted compound (25) was inactive, while the cyclopentyl substituted compound (26) showed a 47-fold improvement in potency. A tetrahydropyran substitution (27) at the 6-position led to a major loss in potency. However, when the substitution at the 6-position is replaced with a large morpholinobenzyl (compound 28), potency was improved.
    Table 2. Initial SAR on the Indoline Core
    a

    EZH2 IC50 of the active/inactive enantiomer.

    The addition of a methyl group at the indoline 3-position resulted in enantiomeric pairs of compounds. After separation of the enantiomers, the active enantiomer of 29 possessed significantly improved potency (IC50 = 0.029 Î¼M) while the inactive one was dramatically less potent (6.98 Î¼M). Lastly, additional modifications at the R2 position, while keeping the tetrahydropyran (THP) group at the 1-position and a methyl group at 3-position, resulted in optimized compound 30 (Table 2) with improved potency (IC50 = 0.011 Î¼M), good kinetic solubility in PBS, and oxidative stability in human and mouse liver microsomes.

    2.1.2. Pyridone Indazole

    Scientists at Epizyme carried out a high-throughput screen of 175â¯000 compounds from their chemical library, which produced inhibitors of varying chemotypes with IC50 values in the 3â30 Î¼M range.(66) They clustered the hits according to chemical structure similarity and screened additional analogs which led to compound 31 (Figure 9) which possessed Ki = 310 nM against PRC2. However, 31 showed poor solubility in initial cellular assays. To overcome this, the structure of 31 was modified initially by incorporating a morpholine group at the 4-position of the phenyl ring (32), resulting in a major improvement in solubility with a slight increase in potency. Replacing the pyrazolopyridine core with indazole led to a 2-fold improvement in potency (33). Finally, increasing the size of the lipophilic group at the 1-position from an isopropyl to a cyclopentyl group produced a significant improvement in potency and led to compound 8 (EPZ-5687). This compound inhibited H3K27 methylation without a substantial decrease in any other histone methyl marks and notably does not disrupt the proteinâprotein interactions among the PRC2 subunits. Finally, 8 was shown to be an equally potent inhibitor of both wild-type and Tyr641 and Ala677 mutants of EZH2.(66)
    Scientists at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute designed new EZH2 inhibitors based on previously reported EZH2 scaffolds and conducted SAR empirically from iterative analog synthesis and biochemical testing.(67) This approach led to 9 (JQEZ5, Figure 10), featuring a pyrazolopyridine core with a 6-substituted solubilizing feature and a preserved pyridone moiety. This compound showed good enzymatic potency of EZH2 (IC50 = 11 nM) and was used to target EZH2 in human lung cancer cell lines.
    Treatment of human oncogene WT NSCLC cell line H661 with 9 resulted in acutely reduced levels of H3K27me3 without affecting H3K27me2/me1, while there was no effect on H3K27me3 levels in the nonsensitive H292 human NSCLC cell line. The proliferation of EZH2-overexpressing H661 and H522 cell lines was suppressed by 9 after treatment for 7 days, while cell lines that were deemed insensitive to EZH2 knockdown were not affected.(67)
    Scientists at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill docked 8 (EPZ-5687) into an EZH2 homology model, which indicated no interaction between the morpholinomethyl moiety and EZH2.(68) In addition, the central amide of 8 formed hydrogen bonds with Asn688 and the pyridone moiety made two hydrogen bonds with His689 in the EZH2 SAM binding site. These observations were used as a means to design a new series of compounds with improved physiochemical properties to enhance oral bioavailability. Among the inhibitors they designed and synthesized, 10 (UNC1999, Figure 11) was also docked into the same model which showed that the secondary amide and pyridone groups maintained the key hydrogen bonds found in other compounds from this chemotype. The indazole was buried in a hydrophobic pocket, and the N-isopropylpiperazine group was directed out toward the solvent. This molecule also showed a 27-fold improvement in potency compared to 8 (IC50 = 54 nM), inhibiting EZH2 (IC50 = 2 nM) and EZH1 (IC50 = 45 nM). Furthermore, 10 had a higher calculated partition coefficient (clogP) value (3.1) than 8 (2.2) and 3 (2.6), which suggested that 10 may have superior oral bioavailability compared with these other two inhibitors. In pharmacokinetics (PK) studies of 10, the drug was administered to mice at escalating doses by intraperitoneal (IP) and oral gavage (PO) routes.(68) It was found that in contrast to 8 (EPZ-5687), which has poor in vivo PK,(66,69)10 is able to achieve relatively high Cmax, with plasma concentrations of nearly 12 Î¼M at the highest tested dose of 150 mg/kg. After IP administration, drugs achieved plasma concentrations above the cellular IC50 for 12â24 h, depending on the dose. Importantly, 10 was also shown to be orally bioavailable. Administration of 50 mg/kg of 10 PO resulted in plasma concentrations above the cellular IC50 for 20 h.
    Compound 10 potently inhibited H3K27me3 in MCF7 cells in a dose-dependent manner and showed low cell toxicity. It inhibited the proliferation of DB cells, which contain a Y641N EZH2 mutation, in a concentration-dependent manner, resulting in complete cell death at 5 Î¼M after an 8-day treatment. Furthermore, after treatment with 3 Î¼M 10 for 3 days, H3K27me3 was significantly reduced, while no significant change in EZH2 protein levels was detected.
    A high-throughput biochemical screen by a group at GlaxoSmithKline led to the identification of small-molecule EZH2 inhibitor 34 (GSK-A, Figure 12) with Kiapp = 700 nM.(70) Extensive medicinal chemistry optimization of this compound produced inhibitor 3 (GSK126, Figure 12).(70) This compound potently inhibited both WT EZH2 and Y641 mutant EZH2 similarly, with Kiapp = 0.5â3 nM. Compound 3 showed greater than 1000-fold selectivity for EZH2 over 20 other human methyltransferases, including both SET-domain-containing and non-SET-domain-containing methyltransferases.(71) Moreover, 3 effectively inhibited the proliferation of EZH2 mutant DLBCL cell lines.
    Mouse pharmacokinetics studies of 3 after a 50 mg/kg intraperitoneal (IP) dose showed the compound achieved high exposure in the blood, with an area under the curve (AUC) of 101 Î¼MÂ·h and a Cmax in blood of 72 Î¼M.(70) In Pfeiffer xenograft tumors, compound 3 attained an exposure of 37 Î¼MÂ·h and a Cmax of 3 Î¼M. While these values far exceeded the in vitro EC50 for 3 in EZH2 inhibition or cell proliferation assays, unbound drug levels were not reported, making it difficult to fully evaluate. Upon treatment in the Karpas422 and Pfeiffer xenograft mouse models, inhibitor 3 induced global decrease in H3K27me3 and an increase in gene expression in a dose-dependent manner. Complete tumor growth inhibition was observed after dosing at 50 mg/kg daily in both models, which was correlated with a statistically significant survival benefit of mice bearing the more aggressive Karpas422 tumors. In addition, inhibitor 3 treatment on peripheral blood of immunocompetent mice revealed no significant changes in any blood cell types.(70) However, one drawback to 3 was its lack of oral bioavailability, which necessitated intravenous (IV) administration in both mouse models and subsequent clinical trials.
    During their extensive SAR studies on 34, the GSK group found that the aza-group at the 7-position of the azaindole core could be removed without losing EZH2 inhibitory activity. The studies also revealed that the cyclopropyl group at the 6-position could be replaced by an amine-containing group similar to 3. Additional diversification of this amine-containing group led to a boost in potency, resulting in compounds 35 and 36 (GSK926 and GSK343, respectively, Figure 13).(72) Both 35 (EZH2 IC50 = 0.02 Î¼M) and 36 (EZH2 IC50 = 0.004 Î¼M) were highly selective EZH2 inhibitors, with decreased potency for EZH1 (2.5 Î¼M and 0.24 Î¼M, respectively). Further investigations of 36 revealed a SAM-competitive mechanism for this compound. An immunofluorescent cell imaging assay revealed that incubation of HCC1806 breast cancer cells with the 35 and 36 for 72 h led to dose-dependent reductions in nuclear H3K27me3. At higher doses (>1000 nM), 35 and 36 achieved greater than 90% inhibition of global H3K27me3 in HCC1806 breast cancer cells and inhibited cell proliferation in all tested prostate and breast cancer cell lines.(72) Unfortunately, compound 36 exhibited high clearance in rat PK studies and therefore was not suitable for additional in vivo studies.

    2.1.3. Pyridone Phenyl

    Using a high-throughput screen of their library, scientists at Epizyme obtained a large number of hits, from which compound 37 (Figure 14), containing a 4,6-dimethylpyridone, was identified as an inhibitor of EZH2 (IC50 = 3.4 Î¼M).(73) Additional similar analogs of hit compound 37 were tested for activity against EZH2, leading to identification of compound 38 as a submicromolar inhibitor of EZH2 (IC50 = 0.5 Î¼M). However, this more-potent analog exhibited poor solubility (<10 Î¼M at pH = 7) and poor oral bioavailability (0.5% F). They investigated the addition of polarity to the molecule, in particular by the introduction of amine groups at the 7-position, which improved solubility without substantial loss in potency (39). These studies led to the identification of lead compound 39 which exhibited significantly higher solubility, oral bioavailability (41% F), and moderate clearance.
    Additional SAR was performed on the core of the molecule, and the indazole showed improvement in potency relative to the pyrazolopyridine core. They then decided to disconnect the five-membered ring of the 5,6-bicyclic ring to give substituted aniline (Table 3), which can be functionalized further to improve activity. R1 substitution was shown to be important to enhance activity in the biochemical assay (40 vs 41). Furthermore, disubstituted anilines showed strong improvements in potency (â¼16-fold) compared to a monosubstituted aniline, leading to optimized ethyl and THP groups on the aniline (compound 44, EZH2 IC50 = 0.01 Î¼M). The combination of the benzylmorpholine tail with the THP-decorated aniline resulted in the development of compound 1 (EPZ-6438, tazemetostat, Figure 15) which showed excellent potency, low clearance, and good bioavailability.
    Table 3. Optimization of Substitution on the Benzene Core
    An in vivo study in mice bearing subcutaneous (SC) G401 xenografts showed that 1 (EPZ-6438) was well tolerated at all doses tested (oral dosing at 250â500 mg/kg twice daily) with minimal effect on body weight. In addition, tumor growth and H3K27me3 level were significantly inhibited for 21â28 days.(74) Pharmacokinetics studies showed that even at the lowest dose of 125 mg/kg BID, after 21 days the plasma concentration was approximately 8 Î¼M 3 h after the last dose and there was a clear relationship between dose and plasma concentration. Later, the same group found that 1 inhibited intracellular H3K27me3 in a concentration- and time-dependent manner in lymphoma cells carrying wild-type and mutant EZH2, and this inhibition selectively killed cells bearing mutant EZH2. In addition, inhibitor 1 caused dose-dependent tumor growth inhibition in multiple EZH2 mutant lymphoma xenografts. Compound 1 (EPZ-6438) is currently under investigation in multiple clinical trials for the treatment of multiple solid tumors such as lymphoma or INI1-deficient tumors (Table 1).(73,75)
    Further optimization of the THP-substituent of 1 and replacement of its second benzene ring with an acetylene linker led to the formation of 45 (EPZ011989, Figure 16).(76) This compound showed equipotent inhibition of WT and mutant EZH2 with an inhibition constant (Ki) of <3 nM. It was also 15-fold selective for EZH2 over EZH1. Compound 45 exhibited good metabolic stability and oral exposure. In rat PK studies, a 300 mg/kg PO dose of 45 provided Cmax = 2.9 Î¼g/mL and AUC = 10â¯000 hÂ·ng/mL, which was predicted to be above the lowest cytotoxic concentration (LCC) for 10 h. These data led to its testing in a xenograft model. Inhibitor 45 displayed significant tumor growth inhibition when examined in EZH2 mutant Karpas422 human DLBCL xenografts, dosing orally at 250 or 500 mg/kg for 21 days, with a minimal effect (5â10% reduction) on body weight. Robust H3K27me3 reduction was detected over the 12-h time course with 7-day treatment for both doses.(76)
    Scientists at Shanghai Hengrui Pharmaceutical designed new EZH2 inhibitors with a strategy of decreasing the complexity and molecular weight of 1.(77) They envisioned that analogs bearing 6,5-fused heteroarenes (Figure 17) such as benzofuran (compound 46) and benzothiophene (compound 47) would maintain similar binding interactions to the protein in the orthosteric pocket. Both compounds showed comparable potency to 1 (EPZ-6438) in the EZH2 biochemical assay with IC50 values in the single-digit nanomolar range. Benzofuran 46 displayed more potent activity (IC50 = 240 nM) in inhibiting the growth of Pfeffier cells compared to benzothiophene 47 (IC50 = 1830 nM). On the basis of these preliminary results, they focused their SAR efforts on the benzofuran series to improve potency and bioavailability of 46.
    The SAR results (Table 4) showed that switching R3 from methyl (compound 46) to methoxy (48) led to similar enzymatic activity but an 11-fold improvement (IC50 = 20 nM) in an assay for Pfeiffer cell proliferation inhibition. In addition, the 2-methyl substitution at R1 (49) was preferred over the 3-methyl substitution (50) since the latter exhibited weaker potency with an IC50 of 1.3 Î¼M. In an attempt to reduce metabolic issues, a drug-like fragment such as morpholinyl (compounds 51 and 52) was introduced at R1 while R2 was substituted with an ethyl group. Changing the R3 group to methyl led to similar Pfeiffer IC50 values (14 nM). Lastly, additional substituents at R3 were evaluated leading to the substituted piperidinyl compound (11), which showed improved potency and liver microsomal stability (>0.5 h). The inhibitor 11 (EBI-2511) significantly reduced the H3K27me3 level in a dose-dependent manner in both Pfeiffer and WSU-DLCL2 cells, although WSU-DLCL2 cells were more resistant (IC50 = 55 nM versus 8 nM for Pfeiffer cells). On the basis of the superior potency against Pfeiffer cell proliferation, it was also tested by oral administration in a Pfeiffer xenograft mouse model. Compound 11 displayed a dose-dependent tumor growth inhibition, with 28% (10 mg/kg), 83% (30 mg/kg), and 97% (100 mg/kg) reduction in tumor size,(77) suggesting potential utility as a treatment for non-Hodgkinâs lymphoma. Plasma concentrations of 11 at the 10 mg/kg PO dose showed it attained Cmax = 0.4 Î¼M and an exposure of 1.4 Î¼MÂ·h, which compared favorably to the observed 6 nM EC50 in the in vitro cell viability experiments with Pfeiffer cells.(77)
    Table 4. SAR Results Leading to the Discovery of 11 (EBI-2511)
    a

    The R1 group is attached to the benzofuran 2-position.

    2.1.4. Pyridone 3,4-Dihydroisoquinolin-1(2H)-one

    Scientists at Pfizer synthesized a focused library of 180 compounds based on the dimethylpyridone motif common to many potent EZH2 inhibitors.(78) This library incorporated a variety of substituted heteroaromatic/phenyl/heterocyclic carboxamides, out of which compound 53 (Figure 18) exhibited modest potency (IC50 = 7.2 Î¼M) in inhibiting WT EZH2 in a biochemical assay. Their investigations into modifying the C1 substituents suggested that the torsional angle between the phenyl group and the amide carbonyl moiety played an important role in EZH2 inhibition potency. Their SAR (Figure 18) led to focusing optimization efforts on the six-membered lactam inhibitor series (55) due to its improved human liver microsome (HLM) stability compared to the seven-membered lactam inhibitor (54).
    Additional SAR (Table 5) showed that switching the R1 substituent from methoxy (55) to isopropoxy moiety (56) resulted in 8-fold improvement in the biochemical assay. Compound 56 displayed reasonable biochemical potency against both WT and Y641N mutant EZH2, as well as moderate HLM clearance and permeability. However, compound 56 had significantly reduced cellular potency for H3K27me3 inhibition. It was found that by replacement of the isopropoxy moiety with a chiral tetrahydrofuran (THF) group (57), biochemical potency was maintained and lipophilic efficiency (LipE) was reduced by about 1.5 units. In addition, they found that by incorporating a small substituent such as Cl as the R2 substituent (58), they gained a 3- to 5-fold improvement in cellular potency compared with 57. Finally, replacing the chiral THF moiety with a 2,5-dimethylisoxazole and maintaining the Cl substituent as R2 afforded a highly potent EZH2 inhibitor (59, PF06726304, Figure 19) that was a potent cellular inhibitor of H3K27me3 and had strong antiproliferative effects on Karpas422 cells.
    Table 5. Investigation of the R1 and R2 Substituentsa
    a

    Asterisks (â) indicate the Ki value. IC50 values for 37 could not be accurately determined under assay conditions because of the high potency of the compound.

    It was found that treatment with 59 resulted in decreased H3K27me3 and upregulated EZH2 target genes (TNFRSF21 and PRDM1) in Karpas422 cells containing both wild-type and Y641N mutant EZH2 proteins. Pharmacokinetic studies of 59 showed that a dose of 300 mg/kg was required to achieve a plasma free drug concentration above the in vitro IC90 for at least 6 h. At the 6 h time point, free drug of 59 in the plasma was approximately 1 Î¼M. Compound 59 also displayed robust in vivo antitumor growth activity, with tumor stasis and regression after 20 daysâ treatment at 200 and 300 mg/kg dose levels, respectively. In addition, approximately 55.5% and 66.4% reduction of the H3K27me3 was induced by compound 59 at the two testing dosages, respectively. Moreover, tumor growth inhibition was sustained for at least another 3 weeks after the last dose, suggesting its ability to mediate long-term epigenetic reprogramming in cells.(78) It is worth noting that the doses used in the tumor study with 59 were significantly higher than those used with 1 (EPZ-6438) to achieve antitumor efficacy, indicating significant differences between the two drugs in terms of their PK/PD relationships.
    However, compound 59 also exhibited unfavorable metabolic stability in human liver microsome (HLM)/hepatocyte clearance assays and had poor thermodynamic solubility (2 Î¼g/mL).(79) Pfizer carried out a more comprehensive SAR study around the R-substituent and found that introduction of the oxetane-methoxy group as a replacement for the dimethyl-substituted isoxazole group reduced lipophilicity, which resulted in improved in vitro HLM clearance. At the same time, this substitution increased the moleculeâs sp3 character, which gave better intrinsic solubility. The most potent enantiomer (5, PF068721497, Figure 19) exhibited superior biochemical and cell-based EZH2 inhibition activities compared to 59. They were able to crystallize their lead compound (5) bound to EZH2 (Figure 20). This confirmed that the 4-methoxypyridone substituent of 5 formed favorable hydrogen bond interactions with the backbone carbonyl and amide NH moieties of Trp624 in the EZH2 binding pocket relative to the corresponding 4-methylpyridone group of 59, explaining the subtle potency improvements. To assess the pharmacokinetics of 5, it was dosed at 300 mg/kg BID-PO, which showed a free drug concentration in the plasma that exceeded its in vitro cell viability IC90 against Karpas422 cells for 24 h. Subcutaneous (SC) dosing of 5 resulted in significantly higher plasma free drug concentrations than PO dosing, along with concentrations greater than the Karpas422 IC90 for longer than 24 h. Compound 5 was tested in a xenograft model where it exhibited robust tumor growth inhibition at 100 mg/kg or tumor regression at 300 mg/kg in mice bearing Karpas422 DLBCL tumor xenografts (Y641N EZH2 mutation) with twice-daily oral administration and no significant body weight loss. In addition, once-daily SC dosing of compound 5 at 100 mg/kg induced profound tumor regression, which was also sustained for another 40 days after the termination of 31 days of treatment.(79) The increased efficacy by SC dosing, as compared with PO administration, was likely due to the greater and more sustained plasma concentrations of the drug, which in turn were likely influenced by the decreased first-pass metabolism by SC administration.(79)

    2.1.5. Tetramethylpiperidinyl Benzamides

    Scientists at Constellation Pharmaceuticals originally screened a total of 150â¯000 compounds from their unbiased compound collection, followed by a biochemical assay hit triage that led to the identification of 288 hits.(80,81) Those hits were further assessed using multiple criteria and subsequently screened in additional enzymatic assays, which allowed them to check for nonideal behavior and a preliminary classification of compounds based on potential mechanism of inhibition (MOI). This led to compound 60 (Figure 21), with modest potency of 51 Î¼M against WT EZH2 and a LipE of 3.5. Compound 60 displayed good Hill coefficient (coefficients of 0.7â1.5 were considered) and shifted only with an increase in SAM, suggesting a SAM-competitive mechanism of inhibition. Their initial SAR involved replacement of the O-linker of the bis-phenylether with thio, ketone, sulfone, sulfoxide, and methylene linkages which mostly resulted in loss of EZH2 affinity. Keeping the diphenylether moiety, they evaluated the right-hand aryl ring and found that incorporation of a 2-cyano substituent (61, Figure 21) led to a 15-fold increase in potency, suggesting the cyano nitrogen was making favorable interaction with the binding site in EZH2.
    Additional SAR showed that monosubstitution adjacent to the ether linkage led to 3- to 6-fold improvement in potency over compound 61, with Cl substitution (62) increasing potency 6-fold (0.45 Î¼M) and efficiency (LipE = 5.1). Finally, in an attempt to further improve the biochemical potency of these tetramethylpiperidinyl-class inhibitors, they found that introduction of a six-membered heterocycle (Table 6) enabled sub-100 nM potency against WT EZH2. Modifying the nitrogen aryl substitution from 4-pyridyl (64) to pyridazine (65) and then to pyrimidine (17) led to improvement in both affinity and lipophilic efficiency, resulting in compound 17 as a lead compound suitable for testing in a xenograft model.
    Table 6. Modifications of the Right-Hand Aryl Ring
    Pyrimidine 17 decreased global H3K27me3 in Karpas422 lymphoma cells,(80) and bulk H3K27me3/me2 levels in a dose-dependent manner, without affecting the levels for H3K27me1 and other tested histone trimethylation markers. This compound decreased the viability of a mutant EZH2-containing GCB-DLBCL cell line. However, compound 17 did not inhibit cell viability of WT EZH2-containing OCI-LY19 GCB-DLBCL or PC3 prostate cancer cells in a dose- and time-dependent manner.(81)

    2.1.6. Miscellaneous Compounds

    Scientists at Pfizer developed a biochemical assay to test isolated oligonucleosomes as substrates to inhibit EZH2-mediated methylation.(82) They used a homology model containing cofactor product S-adenosyl homocysteine (SAH) to initiate SAR exploration. From the key interactions with the amino and carboxylic acid groups present in SAH observed, several amide-containing compounds were synthesized. These data revealed that secondary amides bridged by a methylene linker gained potency that was still far lower than SAH. They further explored SAR on compound 66 (Figure 22) based on space predicted to be available according to their modeling.
    The investigation of N-substituted pyrazoles led to the 4-fluorophenyl moiety (67, Figure 22) which showed a 30-fold improvement in potency (IC50 = 1.4 Î¼M) compared to 66 and about a 10-fold improvement compared with SAH. Replacing the 4-fluorophenyl group with a phenyl group (68) led to a further improvement in potency compared to both 67 and SAH. This potent SAH-derived inhibitor of the EZH2 PRC2 complex (compound 68) displayed IC50 values against WT PRC2 (0.27 Î¼M) and Y641N mutant PRC2 (0.07 Î¼M). The compound also had improved lipophilic efficiency and selectivity against other lysine methyltransferases compared to SAH.

    2.2. EED Inhibitors: Chemical Approach and Biological Activity

    The methyltransferase activity of PRC2 is due to the enzymatic function of the SET domain of EZH2. To promote the mono-, di-, and trimethylation of H3K27, existing H3K27 trimethyllysine residues interact with EED to stimulate EZH2 catalytic activity and thereby increase the H3K27me3 histone mark. Besides catalytic inhibitors of EZH2, another strategy that has been explored to inhibit PRC2 activity has been small molecule inhibitors of the EED-H3K27me3 interaction. Inhibiting this proteinâprotein interaction (PPI) would be expected to prevent activation of EZH2 activity by EED-H3K27me3 binding. A potential advantage of this approach is the possibility of increased selectivity in inhibiting EZH2 due to the specific nature of the EED-H3K27me3 interaction, whereas other SET-domain-containing enzymes may be targeted by nonselective enzymatic EZH2 inhibitors.
    Scientists at AbbVie recently described their success in identifying and optimizing a small molecule that inhibits the EED interaction with H3K27me3.(83,84) By use of a thermal-shift-based HTS, moderately potent hit compound 69 was identified with Ki = 0.6 Î¼M in a TR-FRET assay (Figure 23). Initial SAR focused on modifying the benzyl group attached to the pyrrolidine ring nitrogen. A variety of benzyl group substituents were tolerated, with the electron-withdrawing substituents providing enhanced binding (70, 330 nM). It was also found that alkyl groups ortho to the benzylamine further improved binding (71, 12 nM), with cyclization to give the indane affording highly potent EED ligands (72, 11 nM). After confirmation that the indane was the preferred N-substituent, optimization of the pyrrolidine 3-position was pursued. Here it was determined that extended bicyclic groups such as phenylpiperazine (73) gave the best results in the TR-FRET binding assay. Structureâactivity data from further medicinal chemistry optimization also showed that significant modifications to either the pyrrolidine ring or dimethylamino group led to decreased potency which, coupled with structural biology work, suggested this portion of the molecule occupies the same position as the H3K27 lysine residue. Finally, extensive optimization of the piperazine ring was carried out in which a terminal sulfonamide (74, A-395) was found to afford the most potent EED inhibitor (0.31 nM). Notably, it was revealed that the indane amino 2-position epimerized to give a mixture of diastereomers that could not be readily separated and isolated. Therefore, this mixture was used in subsequent biological studies. The derivative of 74 in which the fluoroindane was replaced by a benzyl group (75, A-395N) was synthesized as a negative control compound.
    Extensive biophysical evaluation confirmed the characterization of 74 (A-395) as an EED-binding ligand that disrupts interaction with H3K27. Surface plasmon resonance (SPR) experiments gave KD = 1.5 nM of 74 against EED, and fluorescence thermal shift showed a clear shift in EED melting temperature in the presence of 74, in contrast to the negative control 75 which did not affect the EED melting temperature. X-ray crystallization of 74 bound to EED (ÎEED, residues 77â441) showed a number of notable features (Figure 24). Most interestingly, binding of 74 induced significant conformational changes of the H3K27me3-binding pocket of EED to accommodate ligand binding. The pocket formed by EED residues W364, Y365, and R367 which is normally occupied by the trimethylamine group of H3K27 is remodeled to form a new, larger hydrophobic pocket that accommodates the inhibitor. A new enclosure composed of several aromatic side chains forms a new binding pocket for the 74 central pyrrolidine core.
    Compound 74 was shown to be highly selective for inhibition of H3K27me3 (and H3K27me2, albeit slightly less potently) over a panel of other histones, including several degrees of H3K4, H3K9, H3K36, and H4K20 methylation without affecting total PRC2 protein levels. Screening 74 for antiproliferative activity against a panel of cell lines showed potent ability to inhibit cell growth, with Pfeiffer cells being particularly sensitive (10-day IC50 = 69 nM). Comparing the effects of EED inhibitor 74 to EZH2 catalytic inhibitors 3 (GSK126)(70) and 1 (EPZ-6438)(73) allowed Abbvie scientists to conclude that EED inhibitor 74 (A-395) phenocopies the effects of catalytic EZH2 inhibitors.(83)
    Pharmacokinetics studies of 74 (A-395) showed that subcutaneous (SC) dosing of a relatively high dose of the drug (300 mg/kg) was necessary to achieve suitable target inhibition for subsequent tumor studies. A dose of 300 mg/kg SC was able to achieve free drug concentrations in the plasma greater than the EC90 for at least 48 h. On the basis of these data, dosing 74 twice per week SC at 300 mg/kg in a Pfeiffer xenograft model led to robust antitumor activity (84% TGI), which was stronger than dosing EZH2 catalytic inhibitor 3 (GSK126) at 50 mg/kg IP once-daily for 36 days, which showed a 62% TGI, or the negative control 75 (which showed no activity). Pharmacodynamics studies indicated H3K27me3 levels were also significantly reduced in Pfeiffer tumors after 74 treatment. Importantly, while EZH2 catalytic inhibitors such as 3 can become ineffective due to single point mutations,(85,86) treatment with 74 led to no similar resistance development, suggesting EED inhibitors such as 74 may provide a more durable response.
    Concurrent with the Abbvie publication of their discovery of 74 (A-395), a group at Novartis reported the identification and characterization of another EED inhibitor, 76 (EED226, Figure 25).(87) The Novartis approach carried out a high-throughput screen for compounds that inhibited the ability of PRC2 to methylate a H3K27me0 substrate. This functional HTS led to a number of hits with different mechanisms of action. When they looked at the compounds that inhibited enzymatic activity in a SAM noncompetitive manner, one was characterized as binding to EED in a way that prevented H3K27me3 interaction. It is interesting to note that the Abbvie approach(83,88) and the present Novartis approach both ended up with molecules that inhibited EED-H3K27me3 binding but did so based on different HTS approaches. Specifically, the Abbvie group looked for direct binders of purified EED and followed up on those that inhibited H3K27me3 formation. Conversely, Novartis used the entire PRC2 complex and measured inhibition of H3K37 methylation as a readout, which was followed by detailed mechanism of action studies to identify compounds that acted by an EED-H3K27me3 PPI mechanism.
    Subsequent medicinal chemistry optimization of one of the Novartis SAM-noncompetitive hits led to the creation of potent EED inhibitor 76,(89) which has IC50 = 23.4 nM. It was found that 76 binds to the H3K27me3 binding pocket of EED (Figure 26) and specifically inhibits H3K27 methylation in both WT EZH2 (G401) cells and mutant EZH2 (Karpas422) cells. Interestingly, synthesis of the biotinylated version of 76 allowed them to perform pull-down studies which showed that only PRC2 members EED, EZH2, SUZ12, and the PRC2-recruitng protein MTF2 were pulled down in Karpas422 lysate. Gene expression microarray and ChIP-PCR studies showed significant increase in PRC2-regulated gene expression upon treatment with 76. Moreover, similar gene expression changes were seen when using either the EED inhibitor 76 or the EZH2 catalytic inhibitor 7 (EI1), a result that is consistent with the work by Abbvie with their EED inhibitor 74 (A-395).(83)
    Subsequently, in vivo studies showed that orally administered 76 induced a dose-dependent decrease in global H3K27me3 and proportionally upregulated PRC2 target genes in a Karpas422 mouse xenograft model with 21 daysâ treatment. In addition, neither body-weight loss nor obvious adverse effects were observed. Moreover, complete tumor regression was induced at a dose of 40 mg/kg, and tumor growth was also inhibited and reached stasis with a 4 mg/kg dose for 32 days. Bioanalysis of plasma from the efficacy study showed 76 achieved a concentration of >30 Î¼M after a single PO dose of 40 mg/kg. Interestingly, although 76 has not progressed into clinical trials, Novartis has developed another EED inhibitor based on this scaffold, 77 (MAK683, Figure 25). While 77 has not been described in detail in the literature, it is currently being studied in clinical trials for treating lymphoma.
    Scientists at Shanghai Blueray Biopharma employed a different strategy in their development of an EED inhibitor.(90) Using the known EED inhibitor 76(87) as a template, they carried out a scaffold-hopping approach to identify new core replacements. Subsequent lead optimization resulted in the identification of 78 as a novel and potent EED inhibitor (Figure 25).(90) This compound was shown to bind to EED by fluorescence thermal shift and competitively displaced H3K27me3 from EED with a potency of 4.5 nM. The competitive displacement of H3K27me3, along with X-ray crystal structure data, confirmed that the molecule binds to EED in the H3K27me3-binding site.
    On the basis of a recent study showing a correlation between MLL and H3K27ac in EZH2 inhibitor resistance,(91) the authors tested 78 against a panel of cell lines that contained varying levels of MLL expression. Differing levels of sensitivity to 78 were observed in the various cell lines. On the basis of measurements of both MLL and H3K27ac in these lines, the authors concluded that H3K27ac was primarily responsible for resistance (i.e., high levels of H3K27ac led to 78 resistance).
    In Karpas422 and Pfeiffer xenograft models, twice-daily oral dosing of 78 for 36 days at 40 or 100 mg/kg induced tumor inhibition with 85% and 96% TGI, respectively. Compound 78 treatment in these models caused substantial decrease of H3K27me3 in a dose-dependent manner and upregulated PRC2 target genes. Moreover, 78 was also efficacious in suppressing syngeneic CT26 colon tumor. Administration of 78 by oral dosing of 30 mg/kg resulted in 59% tumor growth suppression and increased frequency of effector CD8+ T-cell infiltrates in tumors.(90)
    Scientists at the University of Michigan recently described a new series of EED inhibitors based on the cocrystal structure of 76 (Figure 27).(92) The key interactions between 76 and the EED protein (Figure 27) provided a foundation for structure-guided design and optimization of the new series starting with compound 79.(93) The addition of an electron withdrawing group (ester group) on the imidazo[1,5-c]pyrimidine core of 79 led to a 2-fold improvement in the binding affinity of compound 80 to EED as well as inhibition of cell growth in Karpas422 cells, resulting in compound 80 as the lead compound for SAR optimization.
    Initial work studied the replacement of the metabolically liable furan group with other aromatic rings (Table 7). Replacing the furan group with a phenyl group led to a major decrease in both the EED-H3K27me3 peptide competition binding assay and cell growth inhibition assay. However, addition of a fluorine group at C6 in the 2-methoxyphenyl ring (81) led to slight improvement in binding (IC50 = 50 nM) and a 3-fold increase in cell growth inhibition potency in Karpas422 cells (IC50 = 300 nM) compared to compound 80. Further exploration of the deep binding pocket led to replacing the phenyl ring in compound 81 with a benzo[d][1,3]dioxole moiety (82), which resulted in an increase in binding to EED (IC50 = 40 nM) and similar cell growth inhibitory activity. Compound 84 showed the preferred position of oxygen leading to a 7-fold increase in potency compared with 83 in binding to EED, and 30-fold greater potency than 83 in cell growth inhibition in Karpas422 cells. Finally, introduction of a 6-fluoro substituent on the phenyl ring (85) led to improvement in potency in both binding to EED and cell growth inhibition. A similar 5-fluoro-2,3-dihydroenzofuran moiety was also used by Novartis for their EED inhibitor 77 (MAK683) and turned out to be the best replacement for the metabolically labile furan ring in this study.
    Table 7. SAR to Replace the Metabolically Labile Furan Ring
    a

    Cell growth inhibition in Karpas422 cells.

    Compound 85 was further optimized by studying additional modifications of the ethyl ester electron withdrawing group leading to a methylsulfone moiety (86) with subnanomolar potency in binding to EED, IC50 = 0.7 nM (Figure 28). Further modifications on the tail part of the inhibitors, involving replacing the phenyl ring with 3-pyridine, were carried out to improve their solubility. In addition, they investigated different substituents at the 4-position of 3-pyridine and also nonaromatic replacements of the phenyl ring, leading to the identification of the 4-cyclopropyl-3-pyridine moiety (87, EEDi-5285) as the optimal group resulting in 3- to 4-fold improvement in potency in both binding to EED and inhibition of Karpas422 cell growth.
    Pharmacokinetic studies revealed that 87 (EEDi-5285) has an excellent PK profile in mice, with Cmax = 1.8 Î¼M, AUC = 6.0 hÂ·Î¼g/mL after 10 mg/kg oral administration, and an oral bioavailability (F) of 75%. In Karpas422 xenograft models, daily treatment with PO administration of 87 at 50 and 100 mg/kg doses for 28 days resulted in complete tumor regression. No regrowth of the tumors was observed after treatment had been stopped for 72 h. Lastly, a single oral dose of 100 mg/kg of 87 effectively decreased the H3K27me3 level at 24 h.
    A group at Novartis recently published work on the identification and characterization of EED binders that inhibit interaction with H3K27me3.(94,95) While one of these hit series led to the development of compound 76(87) and related analogs, another hit was pursued that acted according to a different mechanism. After performing a screen for biochemical inhibitors of PRC2 activity, inhibitor 88 was interestingly found to be noncompetitive with SAM and H3K27me0 (Figure 29). On the basis of these data and X-ray structural analysis (Figure 30), the inhibitor was found to bind in the H3K27me3-binding site on EED. The molecule was deconstructed because of its relatively inefficient inhibition (2.6 Î¼M IC50 with a molecular weight of 352) to define an active fragment that retained significant inhibition (89). Extensive medicinal chemistry optimization was undertaken to improve the inhibitorâs potency and physiochemical properties (Figure 29). Elaboration of the amine group into various arginine-like motifs found that the 2-aminoimidazole group provided improved potency compared to the secondary amine while also lowering the compoundsâ pKa and concurrently increasing its cell permeability (90, Figure 29). Incorporation of the guanidine moiety as a 2-aminoimidazole fragment (91) further improved the inhibitorâs properties. Further optimization of this core structure found that the small alkyl isopropyl group (92) and the 2-fluoro-5-methoxybenzyl group afforded compound 93 which has an IC50 of 0.43 Î¼M in the biochemical assay and 2.9 Î¼M in the cellular G-401 assay. Finally, evaluation of this compound for its effect on cell proliferation showed that it inhibited Pfeiffer cell proliferation with EC50 = 4.4 Î¼M after 6 daysâ treatment.
    A group at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill has recently described an alternative approach for targeting EED.(96) On the basis of the structure of the EED-binding peptide derived from trimethylated jumonji, AT-rich interactive domain 2 (Jarid2),(47) a minimally effective 5-amino acid peptide (94, Figure 31), was identified that bound to the same region as H3K27me3 and inhibited PRC2 function. Combinatorial peptide library synthesis using the split-and-pool approach, followed by lead optimization, resulted in the identification of compounds 95 (UNC5114) and 96 (UNC5115). These two compounds displayed low single-digit micromolar potency in a fluorescence polarization (FP) ligand displacement assay and submicromolar binding affinity by ITC. These compounds were shown to inhibit PRC2 enzymatic methyltransferase activity with potency between 2 and 4 Î¼M. On-target activity was further confirmed by synthesizing a biotinylated derivative of 95 and performing pull-down studies on PC3 cell lysate, which showed that the peptide inhibitor pulled down all three PRC2 components, EZH2, EED, and SUZ12.
    In follow-up work, the same group used these peptidic EED inhibitors as a basis upon which to create molecules that activate (instead of inhibit) PRC2.(97) Several EED mutations (including I363M) result in a loss of function for PRC2, which has been implicated in various types of hematological malignancies,(98,99) so activators of PRC2 may have therapeutic utility in these diseases. Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations were used to study the binding interactions between Jarid2 and PRC2 components, including both wild-type and I363M EED. On the basis of differences observed with I363M loss-of-function mutant EED, several new peptide analogs were designed. The group found that two of the compounds, 97 (UNC5635) and 98 (UNC5636), caused an increase in PRC2 activity selectively in the I363M EED complex. These data demonstrated the first compounds known to act as allosteric activators of PRC2.

    2.3. EEDâEZH2 ProteinâProtein Inhibitors. Chemical Approaches and Biological Activity

    Another strategy for inhibiting PRC2 activity has been the use of small molecules to block the EEDâEZH2 interaction, thereby disrupting the PRC2 complex. A recent report demonstrated that the FDA-approved drug 99 (astemizole, Figure 32) could block the EEDâEZH2 interaction and lead to PRC2 destabilization and subsequent degradation.(100) By performing an in silico screen of FDA-approved drugs against a hot-spot on EED where it bound EZH2, 99 was identified as a potential hit and subsequently found to inhibit EEDâEZH2 interaction by fluorescence polarization (FP) assay. Binding was also confirmed by fluorescence thermal shift as well as STD-NMR, in which increasing concentrations of EZH2 peptide were used to show that the molecule bound to EED in an EZH2-competitive manner. Interestingly, it was also found that as 99 disrupted the PRC2 complex, this led to the dose-dependent degradation of all PRC2 core components, EZH2, EED, and SUZ12 in both WT EZH2 (Toledo) and mutant EZH2 (DB) DLBCL cells. Inhibition of the EEDâEZH2 interaction and PRC2 degradation led to a decrease in H3K27me3 which was found to be selective versus a panel of other histone positions. Compound 99 was found to inhibit cell viability of a panel of GCB-DLBCL cell lines with EC50 values in the single-digit micromolar range. Finally, knockdown of EED or EZH2 using shRNA led to dramatically decreased sensitivity of cell viability to compound 99 treatment.
    The natural compound 100 (wedelolactone, Figure 32) binds to EED with moderate affinity (KD = 2.8 Î¼M) and disrupts the EZH2âEED interaction, promoting the degradation of PRC2 core components.(101) Also, 100 modulates PRC2 target genes and tumor-related genes expression in PRC2-dependent cancer cells, including human hepatocellular carcinoma cell lines HepG2, human monocytic leukemia cells THP1, and human myeloid leukemia cell lines K562. Moreover, 100 inhibited cell proliferation, induced apoptosis and cell cycle arrest, and suppressed cell migration in these cell lines at a relatively high concentration of 50 Î¼M.

    2.4. EZH2 Covalent Inhibitors

    Covalent inhibitors have continued to gain attention as a novel strategy for inhibiting target protein.(102) Wang et al. identified 101 (gambogenic acid) and a derivative (102, GNA002, Figure 32) as novel EZH2 inhibitors which specifically and covalently bound to Cys668 within the EZH2-SET domain, promoting its degradation through the COOH terminus of Hsp70-interacting protein (CHIP)-mediated ubiquitination.(103)102 significantly inhibited H3K27me3 and dissociated the functional PRC2 complex and upregulated PRC2-suppressed target genes. Anticancer growth effect of 102in vivo was examined by a Cal-27 xenograft mouse model. Treatment with 102 significantly decreased the size and weight of tumors following oral administration of 100 mg/kg without observed body weight loss. In addition, 102 efficiently decreased EZH2 protein levels in both WT EZH2 (Daudi) and mutant EZH2 (Pfeiffer) cell lines while not affecting EZH2 levels in mutant EZH2-C668S cells.(103)

    2.5. EZH2 Degraders: Chemical Approach and Biological Activity

    Recently, a report by Jin and co-workers described the first targeted degraders of EZH2 (103, MS1943, Figure 33).(104) It is interesting to note that based on their data, solely inhibiting EZH2 without decreasing protein level was insufficient at reducing breast cancer cell proliferation.(104) Therefore, they reasoned that degrading EZH2 would be a more effective approach. Molecular modeling of previously described potent and selective EZH2 inhibitor 105(105) (C24, Figure 33) indicated that the terminal piperazine ring was solvent-exposed and therefore presented an opportunity for attaching degron motifs. The group synthesized a series of molecules wherein the piperazine was attached through a linker to different hydrophobic tags. Although no SAR was shown, the group identified compound 103 (Figure 33) as a promising EZH2 degrader that was further characterized.
    One of the important considerations in the decision to use 105 as the EZH2-binding ligand was its potency and selectivity for EZH2 inhibition. In an enzymatic assay of EZH2 catalytic activity, 103 retained potent inhibition of EZH2, with IC50 = 120 nM, as compared to parent inhibitor 105âs IC50 = 12 nM.(105) The hydrophobic tag compound 103 retained good selectivity as it did not inhibit EZH1, a panel of 45 kinases, or a selection of 43 of 45 GPCR, ion channel, and transporter targets. By use of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) cell line MDA-MB-468 for screening, 103 was shown to decrease the amount of EZH2, while neither the parent catalytic inhibitor (105, Figure 33) nor the adamantyl hydrophobic tag moiety alone (104, AM41-44A, Figure 33) was able to reduce EZH2 protein levels. This effect was concentration- and time-dependent as significant degradation was only observed after 2 days of treatment and with single-digit micromolar concentrations. While 103 is less effective than 105 at suppressing the H3K27me3 mark, 103 was also able to induce degradation of PRC2 component, SUZ12. Interestingly, neither EZH2 catalytic inhibitor 105 nor hydrophobic tag-based degrader 103 caused the degradation of PRC2 component EED. In control experiments, the hydrophobic tag moiety 104 was unable to cause degradation of EZH2 or other PRC2 components by itself. By use of MDA-MB-468 cells treated with 103, addition of the proteasome inhibitor MG132 was able to rescue EZH2 degradation, indicating a role for proteasomal degradation in the process.
    These EZH2 degradation experiments were expanded to a variety of other cell lines which showed EZH2 degradation by 103 (but not by 105) in breast cancer cell lines BT549, HCC70, MDA-MB-231, and MCF7, lymphoma cell lines Karpas422 and SUDHL8, and nonmalignant prostate cancer cell line PNT2. Interestingly, in at least one case (BT549 cells), SUZ12 was degraded in addition to EZH2, suggesting different PRC2 components have varying stability in different cell lines. Having established 103 as an EZH2 degrader, its effects at inhibiting cell proliferation were studied. When tested against a panel of breast cancer and other cell line types, 103 inhibited their proliferation with GI50 values typically in the low single-digit micromolar range, whereas parent catalytic inhibitor 105 was far less potent in all cell lines except Karpas422, in which both compounds were equipotent. Some of the tested cell lines were resistant to the effects of both 103 and 105. Pharmacokinetics studies of 103 showed that IP administration of 50 mg/kg provided a plasma concentration of >1 Î¼M. Once-daily administration of 103 for 7 days also showed that drug levels in both plasma and MDA-MB-468 tumors were above the GI50. After confirmation that 103 was bioavailable using both IP and PO administration, the degrader was tested for antitumor efficacy in the MDA-MB-468 tumor model. With daily administration of 150 mg/kg of 103, tumor growth was completely suppressed in this model. Pharmacodynamics studies confirmed on-target activity of 103, with treated tumors showing decreased numbers of EZH2 and H3K27me3 positive cells and increased apoptosis as indicated by decreased Ki67 and increased cleaved caspase-3. Finally, to better understand the mechanism by which 103 induced apoptosis, 103-sensitive MDA-MB-468 cells and 103-insensitive MDA-MB-231 cells were treated with the compound and RNA-seq studies were performed. On the basis of the analysis of pathways differentially activated and ER stress-related gene transcripts in the two cell lines, it was found that 103 induced apoptosis, at least in part, by causing ER stress and aberrantly activating the unfolded protein response (UPR) pathway.

    2.6. EED Degraders: Chemical Approach and Biological Activity

    Recently, scientists at AstraZeneca described the first proteolysis targeting chimeras (PROTACs) that targeted EED for degradation.(106) Stability and methyltransferase activity of PRC2 require the binding of EED to EZH2 and SUZ12, and studies have shown that disruption of this complex leads to loss of competent PRC2 and its H3K27 methylation activity. With this in mind, design of PROTACs that target EED for degradation would be expected to lead to loss of PRC2 and its activity.
    Beginning with insights gained from the recent report of EED inhibitors (Figure 27),(87,89) the group identified a vector from which a solvent-exposed linker could be attached. PROTACs were made by incorporating a variety of linkers to a von HippelâLindau (VHL) ligand. No SAR was provided, but this work resulted in the synthesis of active degraders 106 (PROTAC 1) and 107 (PROTAC 2, Figure 34) that contained alkyl and phenyl ether linkers, respectively.
    Compounds were thoroughly characterized in a series of experiments to confirm their binding to EED and proteasome-mediated degradation. Notably, incorporation of the PROTAC linker and E3 ligase-binding moiety had relatively little effect on the binding of the bifunctional molecule to EED and of its methyltransferase inhibitory activity. Binding of the PROTACs to EED, as measured by surface plasmon resonance (SPR), gave KD < 1 nM and was within 10Ã of the parent EED inhibitor (108). By use of a TR-FRET assay to measure the formation of the EED-PROTAC-VHL ternary complex, maximum complex formation was observed at around 10 nM, with lower TR-FRET ratios above and below this concentration, suggestive of a commonly seen PROTAC Hook effect.
    Using Karpas422 cells, the PROTACs were shown to induce increasing EED degradation over time, with maximum degradation seen at 48 h. Importantly, in addition to degrading EED, the compounds were also found to cause degradation of EZH2 and SUZ12. On the basis of kinetics experiments, EED is degraded first, followed by EZH2 and then SUZ12. Degradation of these proteins led to loss in the H3K27 trimethylation mark. To confirm the mechanism of action for the EED degraders, Karpas422 cells were co-treated with PROTACs and either the proteasome inhibitor MG132 or the neddylation inhibitor MLN4924 (which inhibits E1 ubiquitin ligase activity). In each case, addition of the agent to suppress the ubiquitin proteasome system (UPS) blocked degradation by the PROTAC, indicating the compounds act by engaging the UPS for PRC2 protein degradation.
    The ability of PROTACs to selectively degrade their protein targets is a characteristic thought to derive from the spatial requirement for the E3 ligase, bifunctional molecule, and target protein to form a particular ternary complex structure that is necessary to induce the transfer of a ubiquitin molecule onto the target protein. While some bifunctional molecules may be able to potently bind the target protein and the E3 ligase, they are unable to promote ternary complex formation that allows ubiquitination to occur and will therefore not promote protein degradation. To assess the selectivity of 106 and 107 degradations of PRC2 proteins, unbiased global proteomics was performed on Karpas422 cells treated with 106. It was found that the only proteins significantly degraded were PRC2 members EED, EZH2, and SUZ12. Finally, to determine the efficacy of the EED degraders at inhibiting cell proliferation, 106 and 107 were added to Karpas422 cells, which contain the gain of function Y641N EZH2 mutation. Cell proliferation was markedly reduced by both PROTACs, particularly at time points of 8, 12, and 14 days. Potency of cell proliferation inhibition was slightly reduced compared to that of parent EED inhibitor 108. The GI50 for 106 and 107 was 57 and 45 nM, respectively, versus GI50 = 14 nM for the EED inhibitor after 14 days. Against a panel of 10 other cell lines, interestingly, 107 was ineffective at inhibiting cell proliferation of all except for the G401 kidney cancer cells. To help understand these results, 106 and 107, along with the parental EED inhibitor, were added to G401 cells and subcellular concentrations measured (Table 8).
    Table 8. Subcellular Localization of EED-Targeting PROTACs
    Â drug concentration (pmol/millionÂ cells)
    Â 106107108
    Â (PROTAC 1)(PROTAC 2)(cappedÂ EEDÂ inhibitor)
    cytoplasm0.03Â Â±Â 0.0034.69Â Â±Â 0.470.34Â Â±Â 0.03
    nucleus0.79Â Â±Â 0.0837.2Â Â±Â 3.720.19Â Â±Â 0.02
    Notably, 107 had significantly higher concentration in both the cytoplasm and nucleus than 106, although in each case nuclear concentrations were far higher than the cytoplasm. The parental EED inhibitor had about 2Ã higher concentration in the cytoplasm than nucleus, and its abundance was similar to 106. On the basis of the measured subcellular PROTAC concentrations and lack of efficacy against a panel of catalytically independent, EZH2-dependent, cell lines, the precise mechanism of EED degradation-dependent antiproliferative effects remains unclear.
    At the same time that scientists from AstraZeneca reported their EED PROTACs,(106) a group from the University of North Carolina (UNC) Chapel Hill reported another set of EED-targeted PROTACs(107) based on the published EED inhibitor 76 (EED226).(89) Similar to the approach taken by AstraZeneca, the UNC group also started by analyzing the crystal structure of 76-related compounds bound to EED (Figure 26). They noted that the existing sulfone group was directed toward the solvent, so their efforts focused on building their linkers off this position. In their report,(107) only six potential PROTACs were described and contained different lengths of either alkyl or polethylene glycol (PEG) chain linkers. Similar to the AstraZeneca report, the UNC EED PROTAC that produced the greatest degradation contained a short (three-carbon) alkyl linker between the 76-derived ligand and the VH032 VHL ligand. The most potent degrader (109, UNC6852) was approximately 5Ã less potent at binding EED than 76 (247 nM versus 45 nM) in a TR-FRET assay (Figure 35). Degradation screening was performed in HeLa cells, and 109 degraded 80% of EED at a concentration of 5 Î¼M.

    3. Conclusion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The PRC2 is the only known protein complex that catalyzes H3K27 methylation which mediates epigenetic silencing. As such, it plays a critical role in the maintenance of embryonic stem cell pluripotency during development. Extensive work has shown that PRC2 and its three core subunits, EZH2, EED, and SUZ12, are reactivated, either through overexpression or gain-of-function mutations, in a wide variety of solid and hematological cancers. This reactivation of PRC2 induces cellular dedifferentiation and cancer cell stemness that are associated with aberrant cell proliferation and motility.(44,108) For these reasons, substantial efforts have been undertaken to discover and develop small molecule drugs to therapeutically target PRC2 and its component proteins. The most prevalent approach has been the development of catalytic inhibitors of the EZH2 methyltransferase enzyme. These efforts have led to the first PRC2-directed drug to be FDA-approved, EPZ-6438 (tazemetostat, Tazverik), which is used to treat epithelioid sarcoma and follicular lymphoma, along with several other drugs in various stages of clinical and preclinical development (Table 1). As additional noncatalytic functions of the PRC2 methyltransferase core subunit EZH2 continue to be discovered, new strategies to target PRC2 activity have been pursued as well. One such new approach that has been described is the discovery of small molecules that bind EED and inhibit its interaction with H3K27 (i.e., EED inhibitors). The reported EED inhibitors generally produce cellular effects similar to those seen with EZH2 catalytic inhibitors, and one of them (MAK683, which is based on the EED226 scaffold) is currently in clinical development.
    In addition to these two approaches, recent work has also explored the use of proximity-inducing agents that target respective PRC2 components for degradation. Several groups have published on the use of EED inhibitor ligands to develop targeted degraders (PROTACs) that induce degradation of EED protein. At the same time, another group has described their work in developing EZH2-targeting degraders that use hydrophobic tags to promote EZH2 degradation. In both of these cases (i.e., EED and EZH2 degradation), the effects may be more profound than reversible inhibitors as they would be expected to eliminate both enzymatic and nonenzymatic functions of PRC2, although the full consequences of PRC2 component degradation are yet to be elucidated.
    The complex nature of PRC2 offers a number of important biological and chemical challenges to the development of new cancer therapeutics. At the same time, it provides unique opportunities by which small molecules acting through new mechanisms can be developed to afford new cancer treatments. As noncanonical functions of PRC2(20,51â54) become better characterized, there will be greater emphasis on inhibiting both catalytic and noncatalytic functions of PRC2 to fully suppress all of its oncogenic roles. Demonstration of the ability to target PRC2 components for degradation also opens up new avenues for therapeutics development against PRC2 with mutated component proteins. For instance, mutations in the catalytic pocket of EZH2 that desensitize the tumor to traditional EZH2 enzymatic inhibitors may still allow a targeted degrader to act by degradation of the protein if it retains sufficient EZH2 affinity. Furthermore, as PROTACs can work using targeting ligands that bind to more sites on a protein than a catalytic inhibitor, there are more options for the development of diverse chemotypes that can target the PRC2 using degrader approaches. Another direction in which PRC2 small molecule approaches may proceed is to increase the tissue specificity of PRC2-directed agents, particularly with targeted degraders. For example, a recent report raises the possibility of directing PROTACs to specific tissues by attaching them to antibodies directed against cancer targets.(109) Additionally, the current FDA-approved EZH2 inhibitor tazemetostat requires high doses for producing efficacy in tumor studies.(74) However, as PROTACs degrade their target protein in a catalytic manner, they may require lower doses that could result in fewer off-target effects and a better safety profile. Finally, as additional PRC2-directed agents are developed, it would be interesting to see their effects when combined with one another. For instance, combining an EED inhibitor such as EED226 (which blocks interaction between EED and H3K27me3) and an EZH2 inhibitor may be significantly more effective at blocking PRC2 activity than either alone. Another intriguing possibility would be combining an agent that degrades a PRC2 component protein with an EZH2 catalytic inhibitor, which could theoretically more fully block all EZH2 function, particularly if the degrader was targeted at a noncatalytic site on the protein.
    With the increased understanding of the role PRC2 plays in normal and pathophysiology a better roadmap has been developed for how to target this complex for treating disease. It is particularly exciting that this comes at the same time as new therapeutic modalities such as proteinâprotein inhibitors and proximity-induced molecules are becoming increasingly sophisticated. One would expect that that the application of new small molecule technologies toward PRC2 will continue to have an increasing impact on treating human disease.
